item.title: Beocord 5000 (4715/4716): Polishing the Plexiglass Cover
item.description: The refurbishment of my Beocord 5000 (4715/4716) is nearly complete. I polished the plexiglass cover today, using the method described previously, and am pleased with the results. The attached photo shows the outcome, with the protective tape still in place on the back portion of the panel.

item.description: It’s a great day! My second Beocord 5000 (specifically models 4715/4716) is functional again and playing in sync with the rest of my setup: the Beomaster 6000 4-Channel and the Beogram 4002. item.title: Beocord 5000 (4715/4716): Installing Rebuilt Rubber Pinch Rollers
item.description: Thorough testing of the Beocord 5000 (4715/4716) tape deck revealed an occasional issue where the leading capstan would cease to move the tape forward. This occurred under specific conditions, particularly when humidity hovered around 60% and room temperature dipped below 65Â°F. As a result, the supply capstan would continue to push the tape forward, causing it to slip out of place between the erase head and the supply pinch roller. Fortunately, the Beocord’s auto-stop function activated quickly enough to prevent damage to the tape.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4715/4716): Extraction of Drive Mechanism
item.description: Having restored a Beocord 5000 before, I’ve refined the process of removing the tape mechanism, simplifying the steps from my previous post and video. I began by removing the plexiglass cover for polishing, which provided better access to the tape mechanism. To prepare for a full recap, I also lifted the preamplifier and radio amplifier boards. The photo shows the unit opened up: ‘Chartz’ from Beoworld.org suggested leaving the solenoid in place during removal, which led me to realize that even loosening the solenoid fixture is unnecessary.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4715/4716): Recapping the Preamplifier and the Radio Amplifier Boards
item.description: Let’s review the Beocord 5000! This model contains many tantalum capacitors that, due to their age (around 35 years), should be replaced. Tantalum capacitors pose a fire risk if they short circuit because of the intense heat released when tantalum reacts with oxygen. While tantalum capacitors were favored in the 1970s due to their smaller size compared to aluminum electrolytic capacitors, advancements in manufacturing have closed the size gap. Today, modern aluminum capacitors can be just as small as the older tantalum ones.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4715/4716): Recapping the Power Supply, Motor Control, Electronic Switch and Operational Control Boards
item.description: The restoration continues! Today, I replaced the remaining electrolytic capacitors on my Beocord 5000 (4715/4716). New electrolytics bring peace of mind! The power supply board, including its reservoir and AC motor capacitors, along with the motor control, electronic switch, and operational control boards, were all addressed: The Motor Control board, responsible for the take-up motor, had only one Tantalum capacitor that needed replacement: Here it is after the replacement: Next is the Electronic Switch board.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4715/4716): Calibrating Recording Current and Bias
item.description: Pleased with the seemingly functional Beocord 5000 (4715/4716) tape mechanism, an initial test recording was conducted using a waveform generator. Playback revealed a 3 dB channel imbalance on the Peak Program Meter (PPM), indicating a calibration issue. This was unsurprising given the deck’s age and highlighted the fortunate performance of a previously rebuilt Beocord 5000 in a Beolab 6000 setup, which operated well without calibration. To establish a solid calibration baseline, a reliable frequency response measurement was deemed essential.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4715/4716): Polishing of Plexiglass Panel
item.description: I’m working on restoring another Beocord 5000 (4715/4716) cassette deck, inspired by the resurgence of cassette tapes. It reminds me of the days when creating mixtapes was a way to express affection, unlike simply sharing Spotify playlists today. I decided to practice polishing a spare Beocord 5000 panel before working on the one for my restoration project. I was concerned about the coating on these plexiglass panels, but it seems like it was only there to enhance shine without affecting the color.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4715/4716): Calibrating the Peak Program Meters (VU Meters)
item.description: After reassembling and successfully testing a Beocord 5000 tape deck, I decided to calibrate its Peak Program Meters (PPMs) according to the service manual. Instead of directly inputting a 300 Hz signal into the Dolby B ICs as the manual suggested, I opted to feed a 25 mV, 300 Hz signal into the Beocord’s inputs while in record mode (paused). Using a multimeter, I adjusted the recording levels to achieve the specified 740 mV RMS output at the Dolby B ICs (pin 7), allowing for the calibration of the PPMs’ 0 dB level.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4715/4716): Exchanging the Belts
item.description: After removing the tape mechanism from the Beocord 5000 (4715) for rebuilding, I replaced the old, worn-out belts. My process was largely based on the one shown in my YouTube video. However, I made one key improvement. I learned that the eject lever’s alignment with the tape mechanism is vital for the eject key to function correctly after reassembly. Previously, I had only marked the position of part #256 (“lever”) with a pencil, leading to time-consuming readjustments.
